revision.text:
{{Infobox University |name=Yale-NUS College |native_name= {{nobold|{{native name|ms|Kolej Yale-NUS}}
{{native name|zh|耶鲁-新加坡国大学院|italics=off}}
{{native name|ta|யேய்ல்-சிங்கப்பூர் தேசிய பல்கலைக்கழகம்|italics=off}}}} |image_name=YNClogo.png |motto = A community of learning,
Founded by two great universities,
In Asia, for the world |location = [[Singapore]] |coor = {{coord|1|17|44|N|103|46|36|E|region:SG_type:edu|display=inline,title}} |campus = {{convert|9.07|acres|km2|abbr=on}} |established=April 2011{{cite web|author=s |url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/milestones/ |title=Milestones - Yale-NUS College |publisher=Yale-nus.edu.sg |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} |type=[[Liberal arts college]] |endowment=S$350 million{{cite web|url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Yale-NUS-Fact-Sheet.pdf |format=PDF |title=Yale-NUS College Fact Sheet |publisher=Yale-nus.edu.sg |accessdate=2015-08-12}} |faculty=101 {{cite web|author= |url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/faculty/ |title=Faculty - Yale-NUS College |publisher=Yale-nus.edu.sg |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} |undergrad=517 {{cite web|author= |url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-over-190-students-to-the-class-of-2019/ |title=Yale-NUS College welcomes over 190 students to the Class of 2019 - Yale-NUS College |publisher=Yale-nus.edu.sg |date=2015-06-22 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} |president=[[Tan Tai Yong]] |colors=Blue and Orange {{Color box|#004B8E|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#F9972A|border=darkgray}} |website=[http://yale-nus.edu.sg/ yale-nus.edu.sg] |city=Singapore|mascot=Halcyon{{cite web|author= |url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vi-2/news/yale-nus-unveils-official-college-mascot/ |title=Yale-NUS Unveils Official Mascot - The Octant |publisher=theoctant.org |date=2017-01-02 |accessdate=2017-01-05}}}} '''Yale-NUS College''' is a [[liberal arts college]] in [[Singapore]]. Established in 2011 as a collaboration between [[Yale University]] and the [[National University of Singapore]], it is the first liberal arts college in Singapore and one of the few in Asia. Yale-NUS is the first institution outside [[New Haven, Connecticut]], that Yale University has developed in its 300-year history, making Yale the first American [[Ivy League]] school to establish a college bearing its name in Asia. Yale-NUS is predominantly a four-year, fully residential undergraduate institution. The first class, the class of 2017, consisted of 157 students entering in 2013. Over several years, the college intends to increase its student body to 1,000 students and its teaching faculty to about 100.{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS Faculty|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/faculty/|website=Yale-NUS College|publisher=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=8 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-over-190-students-to-the-class-of-2019/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg}} Students select their majors (currently there are 14{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/majors/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-18}}) at the end of their second year, after going through two years of the Yale-NUS Common Curriculum, which is "built from scratch by the inaugural faculty, draws on the strengths of established liberal arts traditions, while introducing our students to the diverse intellectual traditions and cultures of Asia and the world". Students graduate with a Bachelor of Arts degree with Honours or a Bachelor of Science degree with Honours from Yale-NUS College, awarded by NUS. The College's first graduating class (Class of 2017 – excluding those who are still completing their concurrent degree programmes, amongst others), comprises 119 students. 103 graduated with a Bachelor of Arts with Honours and 16 with a Bachelor of Science with Honours. The top five majors of choice amongst the students were Arts and Humanities; Philosophy, Politics and Economics; Environmental Studies; Psychology; and Mathematical, Computational and Statistical Sciences. As of Sept. 29 2017, over 90% of the students had secured jobs or university places to pursue graduate studies. Students who received job offers are working in sectors such science & research (12%), consulting (14%), as well as the public sector (17%). Others industries include education and engineering, finance, technology and start-ups, communications, and consumer and lifestyle.{{cite news|last1=Hua|first1=Rachel|title=Yale-NUS Graduates Secure Job and Graduate School Opportunities|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/viii-10/news/yale-nus-graduates-secure-job-graduate-school-opportunities/|accessdate=14 November 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=13 November 2017}} About 60% of students at Yale-NUS are Singaporeans and 40% are international students. Yale-NUS College receives more than 8,000 applications annually and the admit rate is typically 3% to 7%.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=David|title=Yale-NUS Welcomes Class of 2021, with 7% acceptance rate|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vii-1/news/yale-nus-welcomes-class-2021-acceptance-rate/|accessdate=14 November 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=18 August 2017}} Apart from [[Singapore University of Technology and Design]], Yale-NUS is the only other college in Singapore to follow a holistic admissions process similar to that followed by Yale and other American universities. Like both Yale and NUS, Yale-NUS follows a [[need-blind]] admission policy and offers financial aid on a full-need basis. Yale-NUS also distributes scholarships to some admitted students based on academic merit.http://yale-nus.edu.sg ==History== Under the presidency of [[Rick Levin|Richard Levin]], Yale University began developing a "internationalization" strategy that included expanding financial resources for international students and study abroad programs, founding the [[Yale World Fellows]] and the [[Yale Center for the Study of Globalization|Center for the Study of Globalization]], and joining the [[International Alliance of Research Universities]].{{cite web |url=http://world.yale.edu/sites/default/files/files/The%20Internationalization%20of%20Yale%20-%20The%20Emerging%20Framework%20.pdf |last1=Levin |first1=Richard C. |last2=Lorimer |first2=Linda K. |title=The Internationalization of Yale: 2005-2008 |date=December 2005 |accessdate=13 March 2015}} Administrators at Yale began considering international campus expansion in 2006,{{cite news |last=Katz |first=Daniel |title=Levin Forges New Ties in Middle East |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2006/09/22/levin-forges-new-ties-in-middle-east/ |date=22 September 2006 |newspaper=Yale Daily News |accessdate=13 March 2015}} and initially approached the [[United Arab Emirates]] about establishing an arts institute on Abu Dhabi's [[Saadiyat Island]], developed in collaboration with the university's arts professional schools.{{cite news |last=Ouroussoff |first=Nicolai |title=A Vision in the Desert |date=1 February 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/01/arts/design/04ouro.html |accessdate=13 March 2015}}{{cite magazine |last=Day Lassila |first=Kathrin |title=Worldly Ambitions |date=May 2007 |magazine=Yale Alumni Magazine |url=http://archives.yalealumnimagazine.com/issues/2007_05/q_a.html |accessdate=13 March 2015}}{{cite news |last=Boyd |first=Rachel |title=Arts institute plans intensify |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=13 September 2007 |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2007/09/13/arts-institute-plans-intensify/ |accessdate=13 March 2015}} After Yale indicated that it was not willing to offer Yale degree programs at the proposed institute, the project was dropped.{{cite news |last1=Kaplan |first1=Thomas |last2=Wessel |first2=Nora |title=Yale drops plans for Abu Dhabi |date=11 April 2008 |newspaper=Yale Daily News |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2008/04/11/yale-drops-plans-for-abu-dhabi/ |accessdate=13 March 2015}}{{cite news |last=Lewin |first=Tamar |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/12/education/12yale.html |title=Yale Moves Away From Plans for Link With Abu Dhabi |date=12 April 2008 |newspaper=New York Times |accessdate=15 March 2015}} [[File:NUS, University Cultural Centre 3, Nov 06.JPG|thumb|right|National University of Singapore]] Levin and National University of Singapore President [[Tan Chorh Chuan]] discussed the concept of a joint liberal arts college at the 2009 [[World Economic Forum]] in Davos, Switzerland,{{cite news |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Whats-in-a-Name-For-Yale-in/131794/ |last=Fischer |first=Karin |title=What's in a Name? For Yale in Singapore, A Whole Lot |date=6 May 2012 |newspaper=The Chronicle of Higher Education |accessdate=12 March 2015}} and eighteen months later, Levin and Yale Provost [[Peter Salovey]] circulated to the Yale faculty a prospectus for a liberal arts college in Singapore. Among the given reasons for the initiative were "develop[ing] a novel curriculum spanning Western and Asian cultures" and better preparing students for "an interconnected, interdependent global environment".{{cite web |last1=Levin |first1=Rick |last2=Salovey |first2=Peter |title=Prospectus for a liberal arts college in Singapore |date=12 September 2010 |url=http://communications.yale.edu/sites/default/files/YNC-Prospectus-2010-09.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212093625/http://communications.yale.edu/sites/default/files/YNC-Prospectus-2010-09.pdf |archivedate=12 December 2013 |deadurl=unfit |accessdate=2 August 2016}}{{cite news |last=Caplan-Bricker |first=Nora |title=Yale, Singapore plan new liberal arts college |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=13 September 2010 }} Yale-NUS College was officially launched in April 2011. In July 2012, the College held its ground-breaking ceremony;{{cite web|author= |url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Edvantage/Story/A1Story20120706-357731.html |title=Yale-NUS College holds groundbreaking ceremony |publisher=News.asiaone.com |date=2012-07-06 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} it enrolled its first class of students in 2013.{{cite web|title=Milestones|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/milestones/|website=Yale–NUS College|accessdate=2 August 2016}} Yale-NUS inaugurated its campus on October 12, 2015. The event was attended by Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, Acting Education Minister (Higher Education) Ong Ye Kung and the presidents of Yale and the National University of Singapore.{{cite news|last1=Pham|first1=Le Vi|title=PM Lee: Yale-NUS Must Be More Than Carbon Copy of Yale - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/issue/news/pm-lee-yale-nus-must-be-more-than-carbon-copy-of-yale/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=12 October 2015}} The College held its inaugural graduation ceremony on May 29, 2017. The certificates were presented by Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam, President of the Republic of Singapore, and Richard Levin, former President of Yale and Chief Executive of Coursera, was the guest speaker.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=David|title=Yale-NUS's Inaugural Class Graduation|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/graduation-issue-i/news/yale-nuss-inaugural-class-graduation/|accessdate=16 June 2017|work=The Octant|agency=The Octant|date=29 May 2017}} The guest speaker for 2018's graduation ceremony will be Professor Kishore Mahbubani, Senior Advisor (University & Global Relations) and Professor in Practice of Policy at the National University of Singapore{{Cite web|url=https://graduation.yale-nus.edu.sg/graduation-speaker/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=graduation.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-08}}. In 2012, Yale-NUS published its policy on academic freedom and non-discrimination, which states that “the College upholds the principles of academic freedom and open inquiry, essential core values in higher education of the highest calibre. Faculty and students in the College will be free to conduct scholarship and research and publish the results, and to teach in the classroom and express themselves on campus, bearing in mind the need to act in accordance with accepted scholarly and professional standards and the regulations of the College.” The College is also “committed to basing judgments concerning the admission, education, and employment of individuals upon their qualifications and abilities.”{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/policies-and-procedures/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-19}} ==Leadership and faculty== [[File:Yale-NUS College.jpg|thumb|right|A picture of the Yale-NUS College campus]] ===Leadership=== * * President, Professor Tan Tai Yong,{{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/leadership/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/new-president-yale-nus-college/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}} Professor of Humanities (History) and previously Vice-Provost (Student Life) at National University of Singapore{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/leadership/tan-tai-yong/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-27}} * Executive Vice President (Academic Affairs), Joanne Roberts,{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/leadership/6567-2/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-08}} Professor of Social Sciences (Economics) at Yale–NUS, and previously on the faculty of the University of Calgary.{{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/leadership/joanne-roberts/|title=Joanne Roberts|last=|first=|date=|website=Yale–NUS College|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 Nov 2018}} * Executive Vice President (Administration), Kristen Lynas, University of Chicago MBA '90 Yale-NUS College's Founding President was [[Pericles Lewis]],{{cite web|url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/index.php/about/president.html|title=President's Welcome|website=Yale–NUS College|accessdate=May 9, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526155011/http://yale-nus.edu.sg/index.php/about/president.html|archivedate=May 26, 2013}} Professor of comparative literature and English at Yale University. President Lewis (2012 – 2017) was instrumental in leading the College to a remarkable number of milestones.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-founding-president-not-seek-second-term-presidency-concludes-may-2017|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}} ===Faculty=== As of August 2016, Yale–NUS lists over 100 faculty members from leading colleges and universities around the world.{{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-announces-new-dean-faculty-senior-faculty-appointments/ |title=Faculty |accessdate=2016-08-02 |website=Yale–NUS College}} ===Governing board=== The governing board is composed of trustees half-appointed by Yale, and half-appointed by NUS.{{cite web |url= http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/the-governing-board/|title= The Governing Board - Yale-NUS College |accessdate= December 4, 2013}} The board is chaired by Mdm. Kay Kuok Oon Kwong.{{cite news|last1=Tan|first1=Joyan|title=A View From Above - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iii-5/features/a-view-from-above/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=16 February 2015}} ==Admissions== Yale-NUS has a no-loan policy and provides need-blind admission to local and international students. The admission timeline is similar to that of colleges and universities in the US.{{Cite news|url=http://admissions.yale-nus.edu.sg/afford/|title=Afford - Yale-NUS College|work=Yale-NUS College|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}} Eventually Yale-NUS hopes to grow its class size to 250 students.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-over-190-students-to-the-class-of-2019/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-08}}{{Update after|2016|7|reason=Hopes from 2013 should have changed by now.}} Application deadlines are typically in January and March.{{cite web|title=Application Deadlines|url=http://admissions.yale-nus.edu.sg/apply/#application-deadlines|website=Yale-NUS College Admissions|publisher=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=26 April 2017}} At full capacity, the total expected student population will be 1,000 students.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-its-largest-student-intake-to-date/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-03}} The College employs a holistic approach in evaluating applicants: while academic achievement as reflected in examinations grades is a primary consideration, interviews, recommendations, essays and extracurricular accomplishments are also given significant weight in the process.{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College welcomes inaugural class exceeding 150 students|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-inaugural-class-exceeding-150-students/|website=Yale-NUS College|publisher=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=26 April 2017}} ===Inaugural class (Class of 2017)=== In all, Yale-NUS attracted more than 11,400 applications from over 130 countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/ |title=Yale-NUS College |publisher=Yale-nus.edu.sg |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} The acceptance rate of the inaugural class was under 4%. making the admission process comparable in selectivity to both [[Yale University]] and the most competitive faculties of [[National University of Singapore]], and making it one of the most selective colleges in the world, as compared to [[Harvard University|Harvard]] (5.9%), [[Stanford University|Stanford]] (5.1%) and [[Columbia University|Columbia]] (6.9%).{{cite web|url=http://www.hernandezcollegeconsulting.com/ivy-league-admission-statistics-overall-2018/ |title=College Admission Statistics | Top Tier Admissions |publisher=Hernandezcollegeconsulting.com |date=2015-05-01 |accessdate=2015-08-12}} According to a press-release by the Yale-NUS College Administration, the overall yield rate was 52% comparable to top liberal arts colleges in the US such as [[Amherst College|Amherst]] (41%), [[Williams College|Williams]] (45%), and [[Bowdoin College|Bowdoin]] (48%), as well as not far off from Ivy League schools and top universities like [[Brown University|Brown]] (58%), [[Cornell University|Cornell]] (52%), [[Columbia University|Columbia]] (61%), [[Harvard University|Harvard]] (81%), [[Stanford University|Stanford]] (76%) and [[Princeton University|Princeton]] (65%).{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2015/01/21/national-universities-where-the-most-accepted-students-enroll |title=National Universities Where the Most Accepted Students Enroll |publisher=US News |date= |accessdate=2015-08-12}} In the fall of 2012, the College began accepting application for the Batch of 2017 from Singapore and the rest of the world. The admissions staff began a series of international recruitment events, spanning North America, Asia, Africa, and Europe. Students were allowed to apply through the [[Common Application]], Yale-NUS portal and those who chose to apply to [[Yale College]] also had the option to share their application with Yale-NUS. ===Class profiles=== Of the 157 students admitted to the class of 2017 (starting in 2013), 87 were female while 70 were male. The median SAT Score was 1440 (on the 1600 scale).{{cite web|url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2013/06/17/yale-nus-releases-inaugural-class-figures/|title=Yale-NUS releases inaugural class figures|publisher=}} The 75th percentile for Critical Reading (CR) is 760/800 and the 75th percentile for Math is 780/800. 26 nationalities from six continents were represented in the first batch. 62% were Singaporean, while the rest were internationals, giving Yale-NUS one of largest international student populations in terms of percentage of total students. Thirty-two of the students were from [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], while another 11 were from [[Europe]], [[Africa]], and [[South America]]. More than 10% of the student body came from [[North America]] with 13 students from the [[United States]] and 4 from [[Canada]]. The Class of 2018 comprised 177 students from 35 countries. They came from 95 schools on six different continents. By nationality, Singaporeans comprise the majority in this intake, with a percentage similar to last year's inaugural class. For international students, the next biggest groups are 10% from the [[United States]], 3% from [[India]], and 3% from [[South Korea]].{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College welcomes more than 170 new students to the Class of 2018|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-more-than-170-new-students-to-the-class-of-2018/|website=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=17 June 2014}} The Class of 2019 comprised 198 students from 25 countries. Singaporeans continued to make up the largest pool of students in this year's intake, similar to the previous two cohorts. The College's international students came from 25 countries, including for the first time, students from [[El Salvador]], [[Jamaica]] and [[Tunisia]]. The nationalities in the Class of 2019 that are most frequently represented are the [[United States]], [[China]] and [[India]].{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College Welcomes Over 190 Students To The Class of 2019|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-college-welcomes-over-190-students-to-the-class-of-2019/|website=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=22 June 2015}} The Class of 2020 comprised more than 200 students from 40 countries, the highest diversity of student nationalities in a single intake. In 2016, the Yale-NUS student body comprises more than 700 students from 53 countries across 6 continents.{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College community officially welcomes new class with First Year Assembly 2016|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/5-august-2016-yale-nus-college-community-officially-welcomes-new-class-first-year-assembly-2016/|website=Yale-NUS College|accessdate=26 April 2017}} A more detailed class profile for the Class of 2020 has not been released,{{cite news|last1=Su|first1=Jasmine|title=Why hasn’t Yale-NUS Released the Admissions Statistics for the Class of 2020?|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-11/news/admissions-statistics-yale-nus/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=18 November 2016}} however the admissions rate of 5% was eventually revealed to the Yale Daily News.{{cite news|last1=Srivastava|first1=Ishaan|title=Yale-NUS posts 5 percent admit rate|url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2017/04/20/yale-nus-posts-5-percent-admit-rate/|accessdate=7 May 2017|publisher=Yale Daily News|date=20 April 2017|language=en}} The Class of 2021 comprised 248 students from 45 countries, its largest intake to date. Singaporeans continued to make up the largest pool of students hailing from 28 schools across Singapore. The College sees the strongest international representation from India, United States, China and South Korea. For the first time, students from Uzbekistan and Paraguay are also represented, amongst others. Acceptance rates have varied between 3 and 7% across the first six batches.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=Dave|title=Yale-NUS Welcomes Class of 2021, with 7% acceptance rate|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vii-1/news/yale-nus-welcomes-class-2021-acceptance-rate/|accessdate=19 September 2017|work=The Octant|issue=Volume 7 Issue 1|publisher=The Octant|date=18 August 2017}} ==Academics== The founding instruction committee decided to implement a common curriculum, a set of interlinked courses for all students. Similar to the core curricula at [[Columbia University]] and [[University of Chicago]], students will a number of set courses in their first year of study. The common curriculum is reviewed every four years. Following its inaugural review, the common curriculum was reduced to 10 courses, with the removal of a science course.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=David|title=Common Curriculum reduced to 10 courses, following first review - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-13/news/common-curriculum-reduced-to-10-courses-following-first-review/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=21 January 2016}} The Yale-NUS common curriculum is a set of interconnected courses designed to provide all students with a shared, intensive exploration of themes and topics ranging across all the academic disciplines, from science to the humanities.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/singapores-first-liberal-arts-college-outlines-innovative-common-curriculum/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-19}} In his book, titled "In Defense of a Liberal Education," Fareed Zakaria describes the Yale-NUS Curriculum Report as the 21st century version of the Yale Report of 1828, which set the agenda for the classical curriculum of the 19th century, and the Harvard Red Book of 1945, which set a similar agenda for the 20th.{{Cite news|url=http://www.libertyproject.com/freedom/why-american-colleges-need-global-common-curriculu/|title=Why American colleges need a global common curriculum in the 21st century|work=The Liberty Project|access-date=2017-07-19}} ===Majors=== Students choose their majors at the end of their second year. Currently, there are 14 major fields of study. 31% of the courses are part of the common curriculum, 34% are required by the major, and 35% are electives and prerequisites for the major.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/student-experience/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-10}} The majors offered are: * Anthropology * Arts and Humanities * Economics * Environmental Studies * Global Affairs * History * Life Sciences * Literature * Mathematics, Computational and Statistical Sciences * Philosophy * Physical Sciences * Philosophy, Politics and Economics * Psychology * Urban Studies {{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/student-experience/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-19}} ===Minors=== Students can declare their minors after the end of their second year. Currently there are 13 minor fields of study. The fields correspond to Yale-NUS's existing majors, with the exception of PPE and DDP Law. However, the college recently approved two new interdisciplinary minors: Global Antiquity and Chinese Studies.{{cite news|last1=Ong|first1=Justin|title=Global Antiquity and Chinese Studies Approved as Yale-NUS’s First Interdisciplinary Minors|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vi-8/news/global-antiquity-chinese-studies-approved-yale-nus-first-interdisciplinary-minor/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|issue=Volume VI Issue 8|publisher=The Octant|date=6 April 2017}} 42% of the inaugural two batches have declared minors.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=David|title=42% of Yale-NUS Upperclass Students Declare Minor|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/issue/news/yale-nus-students-declare-minor/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=2 April 2017}} ==Joint and associated programs== Yale-NUS and Faculty of Law, NUS jointly offer a Double Degree program in Law and Liberal Arts for those seeking a broad liberal arts education in addition to their professional training in the law.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/double-degree-with-law/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-31}} Yale-NUS offers three Concurrent Degree Programs: · Concurrent Degree Program with Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. A five-year program designed for students who want to pursue careers in an environmental field.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/concurrent-degree-with-yfes/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-31}} · Concurrent Degree Program with Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy. A five-year program designed for students who want a broad liberal arts education followed by careers in the field of public policy.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/concurrent-degree-with-lkyspp/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-31}} · Concurrent Degree Program with Yale School of Public Health. A five-year program designed for students who want a broad liberal arts education and a career in the field of public health.{{Cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/curriculum/concurrent-degree-with-yale-school-of-public-health/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-31}} Yale-NUS plans to introduce a fourth Concurrent Degree Programme with the NUS School of Computing, in 2018{{cite news|last1=Ho|first1=Dion|title=Yale-NUS Concurrent Degree Programme with NUS School of Computing - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/issue/news/yale-nus-concurrent-degree-programme-nus-school-computing/|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=25 October 2017}}. Students will receive special consideration to be admitted in the Silver Scholars Program of the Yale School of Management. The program provides the unique opportunity to enter the Yale MBA program immediately after undergraduate study to move more quickly toward career goals. Duke-NUS, Singapore's first US-style graduate-entry medical school, has also expressed interest in admitting Yale-NUS graduates for their Doctor of Medicine (MD), PhD and MD/PhD degree programs.{{cite web|url=http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/index.php/learning/md-phd-md-phd-programs-at-duke-nus-graduate-medical-school.html |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601222220/http://yale-nus.edu.sg/index.php/learning/md-phd-md-phd-programs-at-duke-nus-graduate-medical-school.html |title=MD, PhD, MD/PhD Programs at Duke-NUS Medical School| archivedate=June 1, 2013 }} == Experiential learning == The Yale-NUS Centre for International and Professional Experience integrates traditionally separate and often silo-ed components of experience based learning (such as study abroad, summer sessions, internships, career services, leadership and service programming, research attachments) under one roof.{{Cite web|url=https://cipe.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=cipe.yale-nus.edu.sg|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-19}} The Week 7 program takes place in the seventh week of the first semester of the first year – a time when all freshers are enrolled in the same common curriculum courses. During Week 7, all first-year students participate in a faculty-generated initiative that brings student learning out into the world and connects to both faculty interests and themes of the common curriculum.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/world-insight-designing-experiential-learning-yale-nus-college|title=World insight: designing experiential learning at Yale-NUS College|date=2016-07-24|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en}} At Yale-NUS, a term-time study abroad experience is the norm. Some 75 to 80 per cent of students spend a semester elsewhere.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/world-insight-building-study-abroad-programme-works|title=World insight: building a study abroad programme that works|date=2016-12-27|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2017-06-19|language=en}} ==Campus life== ===Residential colleges=== [[File:Yale-NUS 5.jpg|thumb|right|Yale-NUS College's central courtyard]] Yale-NUS's student life is modelled on the [[residential colleges of Yale University|residential colleges of Yale]]. There are three residential colleges named Saga, Elm and Cendana, although there are plans to build a fourth.{{cite news|last1=Marie Lee|first1=Regina|title=Yale-NUS to Open a Fourth Residential College in Four Years - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-3/features/yale-nus-to-open-a-fourth-residential-college-in-four-years/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=1 September 2015}} Each has its own dining hall, courtyard, student suites, sky-gardens, faculty residences, study-spaces, intramural teams, and butteries, informal student-run eateries that are a Yale tradition. Students live in suites of six single rooms. These small-scale communities are arranged vertically in residential towers, which contain both student suites and faculty apartments. Floors are grouped into neighborhoods, each with its own skygarden, a landscaped outdoor space for high-rise buildings that was pioneered in Singapore. The residential community includes a rector (equivalent to the position of a college master at Yale), a vice rector, faculty fellows, advisors, rector's aides, and distinguished visiting fellows. Students will expand their social and leadership skills while enjoying the support of "nested academic communities." [[File:Yale-NUS 2.jpg|thumb|left|A courtyard at Yale-NUS]] Kyle Farley, formerly Dean of Jonathan Edwards College at Yale, served as the first Dean of Students of the college. Brian McAdoo, a geologist and expert in environment studies, formerly of [[Vassar College]], served as the inaugural Rector and is currently rector of Elm college, while Eduardo Lage-Otero, formerly of Trinity College, was named inaugural Vice-Rector and later served as Vice-Rector of Saga College. There is currently no Dean of Students. As the first freshmen transitioned into the collegiate living experience, they were originally aided by Dean's Fellows {{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/21-july-2017-deans-fellows-guides-and-mentors-for-yale-nus-students/|title=Yale-NUS College|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg}}, a group of recent college graduates picked from various higher educational backgrounds, including Amherst, Carleton, Princeton, Reed, Mt. Holyoke, Yale, and NUS. As of 2017, the Dean's Fellow role has shifted, with residential functions now primarily being performed by upper-class students. ===Student organisations=== In 2017, Yale-NUS had 54 student organisations recognised by the Dean of Students Office.{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College|url=https://studentlife.yale-nus.edu.sg/student-activities/student-orgs-directory/|website=studentlife.yale-nus.edu.sg|accessdate=8 May 2017}} The college has a number of student newspapers, magazines and journals. Publications include ''The Octant'', Yale-NUS's most established publication, ''The Mocktant'', its satirical counterpart, ''Tònes'', a multilingual magazine, and the Yale-NUS Society for Academic Research, which publishes academic journals. While not a recognised student organisation, ''The Fox and Hedgehog'', a current and global affairs review, was founded by Yale-NUS students. ==Campus== [[Image:Yale-NUS 3.jpg|thumb|A view of the three residential colleges.]] The Yale-NUS campus is adjacent to NUS University Town{{cite web|title=University Town|url=https://www.google.com.sg/maps/place/University+Town/@1.3060434,103.7707735,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x31da1af575f7ff17:0x1056d4b4bd4641c8!8m2!3d1.306038!4d103.7729622?hl=en|website=Google Maps|accessdate=July 25, 2016}} and the College moved to this permanent campus in July 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/milestones/ |website=Yale–NUS College|accessdate=July 25, 2016 |title=Milestones}} It consists of a central campus green flanked by academic and administrative buildings. The campus was designed by architectural firms Pelli Clark Pelli and Forum Architects (a Singaporean architecture studio), who state that "its architectural style blends the collegiate traditions of Yale with the Southeast Asian cultures through its modernist style ornamented by metalwork patterns inspired by southeast Asian textiles." Unlike the neighbouring University Town, Yale-NUS's campus is built on a grid system.{{cite news|last1=Chia|first1=David|title=Detailing the Distinct Architecture of Yale-NUS - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-10/arts/detailing-the-distinct-architecture-of-yale-nus/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=3 November 2015}} The campus was designed to achieve the highest rating under the Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark, Singapore's benchmark for sustainable design. In addition to visible sustainable design strategies such as the biofiltration pond and the frequent use of natural ventilation, the campus integrates advanced building systems for energy efficiency.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-architect.co.uk/singapore/yale-nus-college|title=Yale-NUS College - Singapore Education Building - e-architect|date=9 February 2010|publisher=}} Yale-NUS's campus was awarded the Green Mark Platinum Award from the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in 2013{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/yale-nus-wins-bca-green-mark-platinum-award/|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|accessdate=8 May 2017}} and the International Architecture Award in 2016.{{cite web|last1=Isabel Ee|first1=Clare|title=Yale-NUS College|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/26-july-2016-yale-nus-college-receives-prestigious-international-architecture-award-2016/|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|accessdate=8 May 2017}} ==Alumni== Upon graduation, Yale-NUS alumni will be receive alumni membership of National University of Singapore and will be international affiliates in the Association of Yale Alumni (AYA), although not membership to the Yale Club of Singapore.{{cite news|last1=Xie|first1=Yihao|title=Yale-NUS Alumni to be International Affiliates in the Association of Yale Alumni - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-9/news/breaking-yale-nus-alumni-to-be-international-affiliates-in-the-association-of-yale-alumni/|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=22 October 2015}} Yale-NUS has its own Alumni Affairs Council and is working to establish a Yale-NUS Club of Singapore. Since graduating its first class in June 2017, Yale-NUS alumni have won several post-graduate awards, including its first Rhodes Scholar{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/education/yale-nus-graduate-awarded-prestigious-rhodes-scholarship|title=Yale-NUS graduate awarded prestigious Rhodes Scholarship|last=|first=|date=|work=The Straits Times|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} and Schwarzman Scholar.{{Cite web|url=https://www.schwarzmanscholars.org/scholar/mollie-saltskog/|title=Schwarzman Scholars Class of 2018 Profiles|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} They have also achieved an employment rate of 93.3%, with a median monthly salary of SGD3,500.{{Cite web|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/ix-6/uncategorized/graduation-statistics-first-cohort-yale-nus-graduates/|title=Graduation statistics from the first cohort of Yale-NUS graduates|last=Ho|first=Dion|date=15 March 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 March 2018}}. == Mascot == Yale-NUS launched the College Mascot in 2017. The Yale-NUS College Mascot - 'Halcyon' - emerged as a representation of the blue-eared kingfisher species found in rarity in Singapore. The orange-and-blue mascot, colours of Yale-NUS, found ready acceptance as it also encapsulates the core identity of a young academic institution in quick and confident ascension, ready to take on the world.{{Cite news|url=http://www.campaignbriefasia.com/2017/03/yale-nus-and-hakuhodo-singapor.html|title=Yale-NUS and Hakuhodo Singapore team up to create the college kingfisher mascot|work=Campaign Brief Asia|access-date=2017-07-19}} The mascot was ratified by the student body on April 7, 2016 after three rounds of voting. Since ratification, the Yale-NUS Student Government held focus group discussions to gather feedback on the mascot design and name. The name Halcyon emerged from one of these student focus group discussions.{{Cite news|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vi-2/news/yale-nus-unveils-official-college-mascot/|title=Yale-NUS Unveils Official College Mascot|date=2017-02-02|work=The Octant|access-date=2017-07-19|language=en-US}} ==Reactions== Observers in the [[New York Times]] and the [[Chronicle of Higher Education]] see Yale's move as part of a larger movement of the globalization of higher education.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/14/nyregion/14yale.html | work=The New York Times | first=Lisa W. | last=Foderaro | title=Yale Plans to Create a College in Singapore | date=13 September 2010}}{{cite news |last=Fischer |first=Karin |url=http://chronicle.com/article/YaleNational-U-of/132563/ |title=Yale and National U. of Singapore Hammer Out New College's Curriculum |newspaper=The Chronicle of Higher Education |date=25 June 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} Yale faced criticism for its involvement in Singapore because of the government's restrictions on freedom of assembly and ban on homosexual activity.{{cite news |first=Karin |last=Fischer |title=With Opening Near, Yale Defends Singapore Venture |newspaper=The New York Times |date=27 August 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/27/world/asia/27iht-educlede27.html|quote="...few have provoked the heated criticism that Yale has regarding its decision to be involved in a country where not only is freedom of assembly and association restricted, but homosexual activity is banned."}} [[Fareed Zakaria]], a CNN host and fellow of the [[Yale Corporation]] at the time, supported the venture, saying that "Singapore has a great deal to learn from America, and NUS has a great deal to learn from Yale."{{cite news |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/apr/03/zakaria-a-global-education-for-a-global-age/ |last=Zakaria |first=Fareed |title=A global education for a global age |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[Tommy Koh]], former Singaporean Ambassador to the [[United Nations]], called it a "timely and visionary initiative" {{cite web|url=http://www.spp.nus.edu.sg/ips/docs/pub/pa_tk_ST_Yale-NUS%20a%20timely%20visionary%20initiative_150412.pdf |title=Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy |publisher=Spp.nus.edu.sg |date=15 April 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Faculty expressed themselves in the pages of [[Yale Daily News]]. [[Seyla Benhabib]], a [[political philosophy|political philosopher]] at Yale, calling it a "naïve missionary sentiment," asked, "Do we need to go to Singapore to advance interdisciplinarity and a revival of the liberal arts?"{{cite web |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/apr/04/benhabib-whats-stake-yale-nus/ |last=Benhabib |first=Seyla |title=What's at stake at Yale-NUS |publisher=Yale Daily News |date=4 April 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817103617/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/apr/04/benhabib-whats-stake-yale-nus/ |archivedate=17 August 2012 |df= }} The chairs of the faculty search committee responded, "the new college will require faculty to rethink their pedagogical assumptions and to consider such innovations as integrated and interactive approaches to science; writing across the curriculum; computation, computer simulations and interpretation of large data sets; and the honing of quantitative, communication and other skills."{{cite news |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/feb/29/bailyn-davis-and-lewis-rethinking-liberal-arts/?print |last1=Bailyn |first1=Charles |last2=Davis |first2=Deborah |last3=Lewis |first3=Pericles |title=Rethinking liberal arts education |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=29 February 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[Howard Bloch]], a [[Sterling Professor|Sterling Professor of French]], said that "As a nexus between India, China and the West, Singapore’s location favors an important conceptual realignment of the humanities that will be a long time coming to the home campus in New Haven — that is, a synthesis of the ways that ideas and creative works of East and West intersect historically as well as conceptually with each other."{{cite news|url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/mar/19/bloch-why-i-yale-nus/ |last=Bloch |first=Howard |title=Why I like Yale-NUS |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=19 March 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} A group of professors critical of the project characterize the endeavor of "globalizing" a "specious one," saying that the graduates "will have to be conformist, dissent-averse managers and executives who serve the global profit motive."{{cite news |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/mar/21/letters-32112/ |last1=Miller |first1=Christopher |last2=Bers |first2=Victor |last3=Campbell |first3=Jill |last4=Rogers |first4=John |last5=Yiengpruksawan |first5=Mimi |title=LETTERS: 3.21.12 |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=2012-03-21 |accessdate=6 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130210072143/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/mar/21/letters-32112/ |archivedate=10 February 2013 |df= }} Marvin Chun, the master of [[Berkeley College (Yale University)|Berkeley College]] and educated in South Korea, disagreed, asking "Will Yale-NUS be denied to numerous students around the world like me who lack the hyper-talent or mega-resources needed to study abroad at a place like Yale?"{{cite news|url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/apr/05/chun-globalizing-the-academic-1-percent/ |last=Chun |first=Marvin |title= Globalizing the academic 1 percent |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=5 April 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} Others are concerned that Yale-NUS would dilute the Yale name. For [[Michael J. Fischer|Michael Fischer]], professor of computer science, since Yale-NUS will not grant Yale degrees, the value of a Yale degree becomes diminished, and that the joint governing board does not "make Yale-NUS a part of Yale any more than does Levin's service on the board of directors for American Express make American Express a part of Yale."{{cite news |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/mar/23/fischer-yale-nus-is-not-yale/ |last=Fischer |first=Michael |title=Yale-NUS is not Yale |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=23 March 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[Haun Saussy]] stated says that "It’s in the spirit of the motto "Lux et veritas" — my light is not diminished when my neighbor lights his candle at mine, and a truth becomes more powerful, not less, when it is shared." {{cite news |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2010/sep/14/saussy-when-elihu-meets-confucius/ |last=Saussy |first=Haun |title=When Elihu meets Confucius |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=14 September 2010 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} In spring 2012, the Yale College faculty passed a resolution stating, "We urge Yale-NUS to respect, protect and further principles of non-discrimination for all, including sexual minorities and migrant workers; and to uphold civil liberty and political freedom on campus and in the broader society".{{cite web |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2012/apr/06/faculty-approve-yale-nus-resolution |last1=Gideon |first1=Gavan |last2=Woodford |first2=Antonia |title=Faculty approve Yale-NUS resolution |publisher=Yale Daily News |date=2012-04-06 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} In the summer, prompted by a ''Wall Street Journal'' report that students would not be allowed to stage protests or form political parties, [[Human Rights Watch]] stated that it disapproved such restrictions.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303933704577530524046581142 |last=Mahtani |first=Shibani |title=Yale-Singapore Venture to Forbid Political Protest - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=16 July 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}}{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/07/19/singapore-yale-curtail-rights-new-campus |title=Singapore: Yale to Curtail Rights on New Campus | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=19 July 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} [[John Riady]], an Associate Professor of Law at the Pelita Harapan University in Indonesia, defended the venture, stating that "Singapore and Asia are in the middle of great transitions, and Yale has an opportunity to shape that process and put its stamp on a rising continent. In fact, Yale would be doing the cause of liberty a disservice by dropping the project."{{cite news |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/opinion/yale-nus-pact-can-be-a-learning-experience-even-for-the-ivy-league/542112 |title=Yale-NUS Pact Can Be a Learning Experience, Even for the Ivy League |newspaper=The Jakarta Globe |date=4 September 2012 |accessdate=6 September 2013}} Since its founding Yale-NUS has hosted a number of controversial events on its campus, including screening banned documentaries and hosting conversations with activists.{{cite news|last1=Bad|first1=Minsoo|title=Behind the Scenes: Organizing Controversial Events at Yale-NUS - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/vi-3/features/behind-scenes-organising-controversial-events-yale-nus/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=14 March 2017}} In 2015, Yale-NUS became the first higher education institution in Singapore to offer gender neutral housing to students. The move was in response to a push by the inaugural Yale-NUS Student Government.{{cite web|last1=Chappell|first1=David|title=Open Housing|url=http://studentgov.commons.yale-nus.edu.sg/portfolio-item/open-housing/|website=Yale-NUS Student Government|accessdate=7 May 2017|date=17 September 2014}} The project, executed by government representatives David Chappell, Jay Lusk, and Ami Firdaus Bin Mohamed Ali, used a mixture of survey data, student testimonies and statements from student organisations to advocate for the policy change. The move was greeted favourably by students interviewed by the press{{cite news|last1=Teng|first1=Amelia|title=Male, female students in Yale-NUS can soon share suites|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/education/male-female-students-in-yale-nus-can-soon-share-suites|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Straits Times|publisher=The Straits Times|date=22 April 2015|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Bhattacharya|first1=Spandana|last2=Kimmelman|first2=Phoebe|title=Yale-NUS to offer gender neutral housing|url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2015/04/21/yale-nus-to-offer-gender-neutral-housing/|accessdate=7 May 2017|publisher=The Yale Daily News|language=en}} and in the pages of The Octant, one of the college's online student publications.{{cite news|last1=Tay|first1=May|last2=Basu|first2=Meghna|title=Gender Neutral Living: Seminal but Unobtrusive - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iii-12/opinion/gender-neutral-living-seminal-but-unobtrusive/|accessdate=7 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=14 April 2015}} The College received increased media scrutiny in response to student calls for the resignation of Chan Heng Chee, a Yale-NUS Governing Board Member and Singapore's Ambassador-at-Large. Chan defended Section 377A of the Singaporean Penal Code, a law forbidding sodomy, at the United Nations Human Rights Council's Universal Periodic Review in Geneva in January 2016.{{cite news|last1=Xu|first1=Qi|title=Yale-NUS admin speech sparks debate|url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2016/02/05/yale-nus-admin-speech-sparks-debate/|accessdate=8 May 2017|publisher=Yale Daily News|language=en}} In February, The Octant published an op-ed by Nik Carverhill that called on Chan to either take a stand against Section 377A or relinquish her seat on the governing board.{{cite news|last1=Carverhill|first1=Nik|title=On the Yale-NUS Governing Board, Tolerance is Not Enough|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/issue/opinion/on-the-yale-nus-governing-board-tolerance-is-not-enough/|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=3 February 2016}} The article received coverage in the Singaporean press.{{cite news|last1=Heng|first1=Janice|title=Yale-NUS rejects call on envoy to quit post|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/yale-nus-rejects-call-on-envoy-to-quit-post|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=The Straits Times|publisher=The Straits Times|date=7 February 2016|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Tan|first1=Jeanette|title=Some Yale-NUS students want Ambassador-at-Large Chan Heng Chee removed from the school’s board {{!}} Mothership.SG|url=http://mothership.sg/2016/02/some-yale-nus-students-want-ambassador-at-large-chan-heng-chee-removed-from-the-schools-board/|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=mothership.sg|publisher=mothership.sg}} In response, Chan attended a closed door dialogue in March, hosted by the Yale-NUS Student Government and The G Spot, a gender and sexuality alliance on campus, to discuss Singapore's approach to human-rights.{{cite web|last1=Kamarudin|first1=Diyanah|title=Yale-NUS College|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/newsroom/5-july-2016-daryl-yang-class-2018-engaging-dialogue-key-diversity/|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|accessdate=8 May 2017}} 87% of students surveyed by The Octant said that they did not think Chan should resign, although 62% of respondents supported the dialogue.{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=David|last2=Bhattacharya|first2=Spandana|title=Students Reject Call for Ambassador Chan Heng Chee’s resignation: Survey - The Octant|url=http://theoctant.org/edition/iv-15/news/students-reject-call-for-ambassador-chan-heng-chees-resignation/|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=The Octant|publisher=The Octant|date=16 February 2016}} Chan remains a member of the Yale-NUS governing board.{{cite web|title=Yale-NUS College|url=https://www.yale-nus.edu.sg/about/the-governing-board/|website=www.yale-nus.edu.sg|accessdate=8 May 2017}} Reports in the [http://www.chronicle.com/article/Singapore-Meets-the-Ivy/141461/ Chronicle of Higher Education], [https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/yale-nus-college-extends-reach-liberal-arts-forbidden-fruits Times Higher Education], [http://www.barrons.com/articles/yale-goes-to-asia-1425704378?tesla=y Barron’s Magazine] and [http://harvardmagazine.com/2017/07/an-educated-core Harvard Magazine] on the new college, which started classes in August 2013, noted that lively discussions take place on campus. Barron's Magazine's article “Yale goes to Asia” highlighted how education experts such as Ben Nelson, CEO of the Minerva Project, particularly likes Yale-NUS’ emphasis on seminars and its requirement that all students in their first two years take pretty much the same core curriculum, including philosophy and political thought, literature and humanities, and modern social thought. In an article for The Atlantic, Michael Roth, President of Wesleyan University and author of ''Beyond the University: Why Liberal Education Matters'' write about how he was impressed by Yale-NUS’ decision to decline to institutionalize faculty within departments representing the academic disciplines. This has led to a re-conceptualization of majors as complements to a core curriculum, and, in turn, to the welcoming of faculty with diverse skill sets over those tethered to divisive academic specializations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2015/10/american-liberal-education-happens-better-in-singapore/410869/?single_page=true&print|title=The Ironic Birth of Liberal-Arts Education in Asia|last=Roth|first=Michael|work=The Atlantic|access-date=2017-08-15|language=en-US}} ==See also== *[[List of universities and colleges in Singapore]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.yale-nus.edu.sg Yale-NUS College] * [http://ywww.yalenusblog.com Yale-NUS Blog] {{National University of Singapore}} {{Yale}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yale-NUS College}} [[Category:Yale University]] [[Category:National University of Singapore]] [[Category:Liberal arts colleges]]

The '''Yamartino method''' is an algorithm for calculating an approximation of [[wind direction]] during a single pass through the incoming data.<ref> {{cite journal | author = Yamartino, R.J. | year = 1984 | title = A Comparison of Several "Single-Pass" Estimators of the Standard Deviation of Wind Direction | journal = Journal of Climate and Applied Meteorology | volume = 23 | issue = 9 | pages = 1362–1366 | bibcode = 1984JApMe..23.1362Y | doi = 10.1175/1520-0450(1984)023<1362:ACOSPE>2.0.CO;2 }}</ref>
==Background== The standard deviation of wind direction is a measure of lateral [[turbulence]] and is used in a method for estimating the [[Air pollution dispersion terminology#The Pasquill atmospheric stability classes|Pasquill stability category]] in air pollution dispersion.
The simple method for calculating standard deviation requires two passes through the list of values. The first pass determines the average of those values; the second pass determines the sum of the squares of the differences between the values and the average. This double-pass method requires access to all values. A [[Standard deviation#Rapid calculation methods|single-pass method]] can be used for normal data but is unsuitable for [[Polar coordinate system|angular]] data such as wind direction where the 0°/360° (or ±180°) discontinuity forces special consideration. For example, the directions 1°, 0°, and 359° (or −1°) should not average to the direction 180°.
The Yamartino method, introduced by Robert J. Yamartino in 1984, solves both problems. The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) has chosen it as the preferred way to compute the standard deviation of wind direction.<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/scram001/guidance/met/mmgrma.pdf Meteorological Monitoring Guidance for Regulatory Modeling Applications (section 6.2.1)]</ref> A further discussion of the Yamartino method, along with other methods of estimating the standard deviation of wind direction can be found in Farrugia & Micallef.
It is possible to calculate the exact standard deviation in one pass. However, that method needs slightly more calculation effort.
==Algorithm== Over the time interval to be averaged across, ''n'' measurements of wind direction (''θ'') will be made and two totals are accumulated without storage of the ''n'' individual values. At the end of the interval the calculations are as follows: with the average values of sin ''θ'' and cos ''θ'' defined as
:<math>s_a = \frac 1 n \sum_{i=1}^n \sin \theta_i,</math>
:<math>c_a = \frac 1 n \sum_{i=1}^n \cos \theta_i.</math>
Then the average wind direction is given via the four-quadrant arctan(x,y) function as
:<math>\theta_a=\arctan(c_a,s_a).</math>
From twenty different functions for ''σ''<sub>''θ''</sub> using variables obtained in a single-pass of the wind direction data, Yamartino found the best function to be
: <math>\sigma_\theta = \arcsin (\varepsilon) \left[1+\left(\tfrac 2 {\sqrt 3} -1\right) \varepsilon^3\right], </math>
where
:<math>\varepsilon=\sqrt{1-(s^2_a+c^2_a)}.</math>
The key here is to remember that sin<sup>2</sup>''θ'' + cos<sup>2</sup>''θ'' = 1 so that for example, with a constant wind direction at any value of ''θ'', the value of <math>\varepsilon</math> will be zero, leading to a zero value for the standard deviation.
The use of <math>\varepsilon</math> alone produces a result close to that produced with a double-pass when the dispersion of angles is small (not crossing the discontinuity), but by construction it is always between 0 and 1. Taking the [[arcsine]] then produces the double-pass answer when there are just two equally common angles: in the extreme case of an oscillating wind blowing backwards and forwards, it produces a result of <math>\tfrac{\pi}{2}</math> radians, i.e. a [[right angle]]. The final factor adjusts this figure upwards so that it produces the double-pass result of <math>\tfrac{\pi}{\sqrt{3}}</math> radians for an almost uniform distribution of angles across all directions, while making minimal change to results for small dispersions.
The theoretical maximum error against the correct double-pass ''σ''<sub>''θ''</sub> is therefore about 15% with an oscillating wind. Comparisons against Monte Carlo generated cases indicate that Yamartino's algorithm is within 2% for more realistic distributions.
A variant might be to weight each wind direction observation by the wind speed at that time.

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = Professor Emeritus | name = Yehuda Liebes | image = Yehuda Liebes.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Liebes in 2012 | native_name = {{Hebrew|יהודה ליבס}} | native_name_lang = [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] | birth_name = <!-- use only if different from full/othernames --> | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1947}} | birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = [[Israelis|Israeli]] | occupation = | known_for = [[Kabbalah]] scholarship | spouse = Esther | children = 3 | awards = [[Israel Prize]] (2017) | website = http://liebes.huji.ac.il/ | education = PhD, [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], 1976 | thesis_title = Peraḳim be-milon sefer ha-Zohar (Chapters in the Dictionary of the Book of the Zohar) | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1976 | doctoral_advisor = [[Gershom Scholem]] | influences = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> | era = | discipline = <!--major academic discipline – e.g. Physicist, Sociologist, New Testament scholar, Ancient Near Eastern Linguist--> | sub_discipline = <!--academic discipline specialist area – e.g. Sub-atomic research, 20th Century Danish specialist, Pauline research, Arcadian and Ugaritic specialist--> | workplaces = Hebrew University of Jerusalem | doctoral_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | notable_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = [[Kabbalah]], [[Zohar]], Jewish [[myth]], [[Sabbateans|Sabbateanism]] | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influenced = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> }} {{Kabbalah}} '''Yehuda Liebes''' ({{lang-he-n|יהודה ליבס}}; born 1947)<ref name=huji>{{cite web |url=http://new.huji.ac.il/en/article/33408|title=Israel Prize to Hebrew University's Prof. Yehuda Liebes|date=5 February 2017|accessdate=4 January 2018|publisher=[[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]}}</ref> is an Israeli academic and scholar. He is the Gershom Scholem Professor Emeritus of Kabbalah at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. He is considered a leading scholar of [[Kabbalah]]; his other research interests include Jewish [[myth]], [[Sabbateans|Sabbateanism]], and the links between [[Judaism]] and [[ancient Greek religion]], [[Christianity]], and [[Islam]]. Author of many books and articles, his work is often cited by other scholars. He is the recipient of the 1997 [[Bialik Prize]], the 1999 Gershom Scholem Prize for Kabbalah Research, the 2006 [[The EMET Prize for Art, Science and Culture| EMET Prize for Art, Science and Culture]], and the 2017 [[Israel Prize]].
==Early life and education== Yehuda Liebes was born in [[Jerusalem]] in 1947.<ref name=huji/> His father, [[:he:יוסף גרהרד ליבס|Joseph Gerhard Liebes]] (1910–1988), a noted Hebrew translator of classic literature, left his native Germany at the age of 18 to study at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. He returned to his homeland to continue his education, but was expelled from his university due to the [[Nuremberg Laws]]. He then undertook agricultural training in [[Latvia]] with a Zionist movement. There he married his first wife, with whom he settled in [[Pardes Hanna-Karkur|Pardes Hanna]] in [[Mandatory Palestine]] and had two daughters before they divorced. In 1941 Liebes married his second wife, Mira, a native of [[Riga]] who had grown up in [[Berlin]].<ref name=haaretz>{{cite web |url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1250272|title=דמותו של פרופ' יהודה ליבס: חוקר קבלה שנוי במחלוקת ודתי ציוני|language=Hebrew|trans-title=Professor Yehuda Liebes: A Controversial Kabbalah Scholar and Religious Zionist|first=Dalia|last=Karpal|date=13 March 2009|accessdate=5 January 2017|work=[[Haaretz]]}}</ref> They had two children, a daughter (Tamar, today head of the Department of Communications at Hebrew University) and a son (Yehuda).<ref name=haaretz/> On his mother's side, Yehuda was a cousin of Israeli intellectual [[Yeshayahu Leibowitz]].<ref name=haaretz/>
Liebes was acquainted with [[Gershom Scholem]], the father of modern Kabbalah scholarship, from an early age, as his parents were friends of Scholem. Scholem attended Yehuda's [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bar Mitzvah]] and gave him as a gift [[:he:ישעיה תשבי|Yeshayahu Tishby]]'s book ''Mishnat HaZohar'' ("The Wisdom of the [[Zohar]]").<ref name=musaf/>
[[File:Scholem card catalog.jpg|125px|left|thumb|[[Gershom Scholem]]'s card catalog]] Liebes graduated from the [[Hebrew University Secondary School]].<ref name=haaretz/> In 1965, he enlisted in the [[Paratroopers Brigade]] for his [[Conscription in Israel|compulsory army service]], and in 1967, served in the [[Six-Day War]] as a non-commissioned officer.<ref name=haaretz/> During [[Reserve duty (Israel)|reserve duty]] in 1969, he was injured during a Palestinian attack on his post in the [[Jordan Valley (Middle East)|Jordan Valley]], lost several teeth, and was hospitalized for several months.<ref name=haaretz/>
In 1967, Liebes began his studies at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.<ref name=huji/> After earning undergraduate and graduate degrees, he pursued his doctoral research under Scholem.<ref name=alan/><ref name=card>{{cite web |url=http://web.nli.org.il/sites/NLI/English/collections/jewish-collection/scholem/scholem-card-catalog/Pages/Scholem-Prologue.aspx|title= Gershom Scholem's Milon HaZohar Card Index|first=Yehuda|last=Liebes|publisher=[[National Library of Israel]]|accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> Scholem gave Liebes access to handwritten note cards he had prepared for a lexicon of [[Zohar]] terminology that he never wrote,<ref name=card/> and Liebes submitted his dissertation on ''Peraḳim be-milon sefer ha-Zohar'' (Chapters in the Dictionary of the Book of the Zohar) (1976).<ref name=haaretz/>
==Teaching career== Liebes began lecturing in the Hebrew University's Department of Jewish Thought in 1971. He became a full professor in 1993.<ref name=haaretz/> His course subjects include Kabbalah, Jewish myth, and the Zohar.<ref name=huji/> He has also taught on Zohar at the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name=huji/>
==Research== [[File:Yehuda libes.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Liebes in 2006]] {{Quote box |width=250px |align=right |quoted=true |bgcolor= |salign=right |quote=I do not really like the term 'Jewish mysticism'. The order of the words is not correct. You have to say 'mystical Judaism', because Kabbalah is first and foremost an interpretation of an aspect of the Jewish religion. … The inclusion of all mystical phenomena under the heading 'mysticism' is a mistake, because it causes people to think everything is the same—Christian mysticism, Jewish mysticism, Muslim mysticism. The Kabbalah is an interpretation of the Jewish religion, of [[Torah]] and [[Mitzva|mitzvot]], of the people and the land of Israel". |source=–Yehuda Liebes, 2017<ref name=musaf/> }} Liebes is considered a leading scholar of Kabbalah.<ref name=alan/><ref name=musaf>{{cite web |url=https://musaf-shabbat.com/2017/02/19/%D7%9C%D7%90%D7%94%D7%95%D7%91-%D7%9E%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%99-%D7%9C%D7%94%D7%99%D7%91%D7%9C%D7%A2-%D7%90%D7%A8%D7%99%D7%90%D7%9C-%D7%94%D7%95%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%91%D7%99%D7%A5/|title=לאהוב מבלי להיבלע|language=Hebrew|trans-title=To Love Without Being Swallowed Up|first=Ariel|last=Horowitz|date=17 February 2017|accessdate=9 January 2018|work=[[Makor Rishon]]}}</ref> His work is said to be representative of "the Hebrew University's new wave of kabbalistic research".<ref name=alan>{{cite web |url=https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/reinterpreting-mysticism-and-messianism/|first=Alan|last=Unterman|title=Reinterpreting Mysticism and Messianism|year=2018|accessdate=4 January 2018|publisher=myjewishlearning.com}}</ref> Liebes explores the mythic and messianic dimensions in Judaism and Kabbalah, and Christian and Sabbatean influences on Kabbalah.<ref name=alan/> He has written extensively on "the Zohar, [[Lurianic Kabbalah]], Sabbateanism, [[Breslov (Hasidic group)|Breslov Hasidism]] and the [[Vilna Gaon|Gaon of Vilna]] and his disciples".<ref name=huji/> He studies the links between [[Judaism]] and [[ancient Greek religion]], [[Christianity]], and [[Islam]].<ref name=huji/><ref name=haaretz/> His work is often cited by scholars.<ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ksTtuOEoQUgC&pg=PA31 |title= The Sinner and the Amnesiac: The Rabbinic Invention of Elisha Ben Abuya and Eleazar Ben Arach|first1= Alon |last1=Goshen-Gottstein|first2=Bertrand |last2=Badie|year=2000|publisher= Stanford University Press|isbn= 0804733872|pages=31-32}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=t7br4uA8ZB4C&pg=PA77 |title='Our Place in Al-Andalus': Kabbalah, Philosophy, Literature in Arab Jewish Letters|first= Gil |last=Anidjar|year=2002|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn= 0804741212|pages=77ff}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=s6cwDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA184 |title= Jews in Poland-Lithuania in the Eighteenth Century: A Genealogy of Modernity|first=Gershon David|last=Hundert|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn= 0520249941|pp=183-5}}</ref><ref>{{citation|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VEzAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA194 |chapter=Rabbi Jonathan Eibeschuetz and the Alleged Jewish-Christian Sect in Eighteenth-Century Amsterdam|first=Sid Z |last=Leiman|title=New Perspectives on Jewish-Christian Relations|editor-first= Elisheva |editor-last=Carlebach|editor2-first=Jacob J.|editor2-last=Schacter|year=2011|publisher=BRILL|isbn= 9004221182|p=194}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=EZsoCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT204 |title=The Revealed and Hidden Writings of Rabbi Nachman of Bratslav: His worlds of revelation and rectification|first=Zvi|last=Mark|year=2015|publisher=Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG|isbn= 3110407779|pages=204-205}}</ref>
Liebes has also translated Greek, Latin, and Arabic religious poetry into Hebrew.<ref name=huji/><ref name=haaretz/>
==Controversial views== Challenging the traditional ascription of the Zohar to the 2nd-century disciples of [[Shimon bar Yochai]] in [[Israel]], Liebes asserts that a group of 13th-century Spanish Kabbalists, which included [[Moses de León]], composed the work, each reflecting his own approach to Kabbalah.<ref name=alan/> Liebes claims that the ''Ketem Paz'' on the Zohar and the Kabbalistic hymn ''[[Bar Yochai (song)|Bar Yochai]]'' were written by two different authors with similar names, not the one [[Shimon Lavi]] who is traditionally credited with authoring both works.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.nli.org.il/sites/nlis/he/Song/pages/Articles/%D7%9E%D7%90%D7%9E%D7%A8_%D7%A8'_%D7%A9%D7%9E%D7%A2%D7%95%D7%9F_%D7%9C%D7%91%D7%99%D7%90.aspx |title= ר' שמעון לביא |language=Hebrew|trans-title=Rabbi Shimon Lavi|publisher=[[National Library of Israel]]|accessdate=5 January 2018}}</ref> Liebes also finds Christian and Sabbatean inspiration in the ideas of Rebbe [[Nachman of Breslov]]<ref name=alan/> and, at the same time, Sabbatean influences on the disciples of the Vilna Gaon [[Misnagdim|who opposed Hasidism]].<ref name=haaretz/>
Liebes angered [[Religious Zionism|National Religious]] Jews in Israel when he claimed to find a Christian allusion in the [[Amidah]], the central prayer of the [[Jewish prayer|Jewish liturgy]]. Liebes asserted that the conclusion of the 14th blessing, "''keren yeshua''" ("horn of salvation") refers not to [[David]], but to [[Jesus]] (''Yeshua'' in Hebrew).<ref name=haaretz/>
Liebes publishes in Hebrew and has expressed opposition to the study of Jewish thought in English. He has allowed only a few of his works to be translated into English, in conjunction with his academic degree and tenure.<ref name=haaretz/>
==Awards and honors== Liebes received the 1997 [[Bialik Prize]] for his book ''The Secret of the Sabbatean Faith'' (1995).<ref name=haaretz/> In 1999 he received the Peace Prize for the study of Kabbalah<ref name=huji/> and the Gershom Scholem Prize for Kabbalah Research.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.academy.ac.il/RichText/GeneralPage.aspx?nodeId=1079|title=Gershom Scholem Prize for Kabbalah Research|publisher=[[Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities]]|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref> He was awarded the 2006 [[The EMET Prize for Art, Science and Culture| EMET Prize for Art, Science and Culture]], in the category of Humanities, for his work on Sabbateanism.<ref name=haaretz/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.emetprize.org/laureates/humanities/jewish-philosophy/prof-yehuda-liebes/|title=Emet Prize Laureates|publisher=Emet Prize for Science, Art and Culture|accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref> In 2017 he received the [[Israel Prize]] for his work on Kabbalah and Jewish mysticism.<ref name=huji/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/380233|title=Israel Prize for Kaballah to Professor Yehuda Liebes|date=5 February 2017|accessdate=21 January 2018|work=[[Arutz Sheva|Israel National News]]}}</ref>
==Personal life== Liebes and his wife Esther have three children. In 1977, after he completed his doctorate, they joined the nucleus of the new community of [[Shilo, Mateh Binyamin|Shilo]], living in a caravan near [[Ofra]], but left after nine months.<ref name=musaf/> The couple resides in the [[Kiryat Moshe]] neighborhood of Jerusalem.<ref name=haaretz/> Esther formerly worked as librarian of the Gershom G. Scholem Collection at the Hebrew University Library.<ref name=musaf/>
Liebes identifies politically with the [[Right-wing politics|extreme right]] and religiously with [[Religious Zionism]].<ref name=haaretz/>
